attributes.title: Barriers and Facilitators to Conducting Clinical Trials using an Adaptive Design

q1.value: Barriers and Facilitators to Conducting Clinical Trials using an Adaptive Design

q2.value: Lisa M Puchalski Ritchie, John Marshall, Srinivas Murthy

q3.value: Well conducted, randomized controlled trials (RCTs) have long been recognized as providing the highest level of evidence of effectiveness (second only to systematic reviews of well conducted RCTs) and as a result have been the standard evaluation of clinical interventions for decades. However, conventional RCTs typically require a substantial amount of time and resources, and as a result are slow to bring benefits of improved clinical interventions to the bedside. In response, adaptive designs have been developed as an alternative to traditional RCTs. Benefits of adaptive trials may make them particularly well suited to ICU/similar high morbidity/mortality health care settings, where appropriate adaptations may allow for more patients to receive promising interventions while still allowing for rigorous evaluation of interventions. However, as researchers have gained experience with adaptive research designs, they have inevitably encountered challenges with implementing and interpreting some types of adaptations.

q4.value: Our goal is to assess physicians’ and researchers’ knowledge, attitudes and beliefs, and perceived/experienced challenges to the use of adaptive design clinical trials, in order to identify and understand barriers to, and facilitators of the use of adaptive clinical trial designs in ICU settings in Canada.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study will employ a multi-component qualitative design that includes: an online survey and interviews with physicians and researchers conducting and/or participating in research in ICU settings in Canada.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The survey will be distributed to members of the CCCTG prior to the summer scientific meeting, with up to 2 reminders at two week intervals sent to achieve 60% or greater completion rate. Interviews will be conducted by an interview team member using a semi-structured interview guide. Interviews will be conducted in a private location and at a time convenient to participants, with interviews expected to last 30 to 60 minutes. Interviews will be audio recorded digitally using unique identifiers only, and transcribed verbatim. A quality check will be conducted on 20% of transcripts by an interview team member to assess for accuracy. If discrepancies are noted, all transcripts will be verified by a second team member and discrepancies resolved through discussion and consultation with the study team as needed.

q13.value:
Participants will include physicians and researchers who are members of the Canadian Critical Care Trials Group (CCCTG), and who conduct and/or participate in research in Canadian ICUs. The survey will be sent out to the groups list serve with all physicians/researcher members invited to participate. Of the approximately 150 physicians and/or researcher CCCTG members, we anticipate a 60% response rate for a total of 90 survey participants. 
Interview participants will be selected from members attending the CCCTG Summerr 2020 Scientific Meeting in June 2020. If saturation is not achieved through face to face interviews with meeting participants during these time blocks, additional interviews will be conducted by secure teleconference. We anticipate 10-15 interviews per group (physicians and researchers), for a total of 20-30 interviews will be required to achieve saturation.

q14.value: We anticipate 10-15 interviews per group (physicians and researchers), for a total of 20-30 interviews will be required to achieve saturation.

question.value: not applicable
demographic data including: professional role, years of research experience, research training, primary practice setting and gender.
not applicable

Descriptive analysis of demographic data will be conducted for survey and interview participants. 

Survey text responses and Interviews will be analyzed qualitatively, independently by two study team members, using thematic content analysis, and data triangulated across data sources and respondent groups (physician, researcher, etc.). Nvivo 12 will be used to code and organize data into themes, and to assess for difference/similarities across key participants groups based on participant group (physician/researcher), practice/research setting, gender and years of experience. A draft coding scheme will be created based on findings of our recently completed scoping review of stakeholders perspectives of adaptable designs, and categories outlined in the theoretical domains framework. The framework will be revised collaboratively following an initial round of independent coding, and revised until a final coding scheme is agreed upon. The final coding scheme will then be applied independently, and discrepancies resolved through discussion and involvement of a third team member as needed.

q25.value: See attached registration for further detail

attributes.title: Effects of erector spinae plane block on postoperative pain and side-effects in adult patients underwent surgery: A systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.

q1.value: Torture vs Murder: Two types of harm judgements across different patients

q3.value: We ran a preliminary study found that people have asymmetric preferences over how morally wrong torture is compared to murder, specifically depending on whether the moral patient was an animal or a human. This project aims to explore this asymmetry further using a wide range of different moral patients both humans and non-human animals. In particular, we wish to see whether measures of mind perception for the different patients (Gray, Gray, & Wegner, 2007), is predictive of peoples’ judgments in this domain.

q4.value:
- Participant’s level of perceived agency and patiency for each patient will best predict judgments comparing torture and murder such that, for example, low levels of agency and high levels of patiency will predict that torture is perceived to be morally worse than murder.

- Alternatively, human patients will all have the same qualitative judgments and judgments of non-human animals will be the reverse, demonstrating that sacred values regarding life (Tetlock, 2003) only apply to human moral patients, independently from how we perceive their mental capacities.

- Exploratory: It is also possible that we find the predictions in 4.2 but only for those not identifying as vegan, which would suggest sacred values over life are malleable and can be extended beyond human animals for some subjects.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a repeated-measures design where subjects will see all agents (11 humans and 11 animals). Non-human animals are: octopus, crab, family dog, cow, sheep, chicken, orangutan, spider, ant, pigeon, police dog. Humans are: doctor, ceo, teacher, child, baby, athlete, warehouse worker, person with a severe mental disability, you - the participant, accountant, bus driver

q9.value: Each animal/human will be presented in random order. Whether participants see the Torture vs Murder questions or the Agency/Experience questionnaires first will be randomised and whether Agency or Experience comes first is also randomised. Randomisation will be achieved through Qualtrics’ native functionality.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Warwick University’s psychology undergraduate student subject pool. Participants will receive course credit taking part in the experiment. Data will be collected online via Qualtrics survey forms.

q13.value: We will be recruiting via email, and we will run the experiment with 100 participants.

q14.value: Sample size based on results from our prior study.

question.value:
We measure each participant’s mind perception with regard to each moral patient on Agency and Experience. This asks to what extent participants: 

“How much each of these targets is capable of thinking. That is, how much is each able to plan ahead, reason about ideas, think, and have general intelligence.” 

and 

“How much each of these targets is capable of feeling. That is, how much can they have emotions and feelings, and experience sensations of pain and pleasure ” 

They are measured on a five-point scale.

In terms of measuring judgments of torture compared to murder, participants are told: 

“For each agent please imagine: 

First that someone, for fun, kills them instantly and painlessly. 

Second  that someone, for fun, captures them and for a short period painfully tortures them before letting them go.  

For each agent you will answer which action you feel is morally worse.”

They are asked which act is more morally wrong on a five-point scale. Participants are also asked whether they consume animal products. They are given three options: (1) No, I am Vegan, (2) Partially, I am a vegetarian (3)Yes.

A rundown of the Analysis Plan is as follows:
Measures
AGENT: 22 Different Agents
AGENT TYPE: Animal / Human
FOOD ORIENTATION: Vegan / Vegetarian / Meat-Eater
AGENCY: 1 - 5
EXPERIENCE: 1 - 5
DIFFERENCE: The difference between AGENCY and EXPERIENCE ratings
RATING: Ranging from Torture is Morally Worse to Killing is Morally Worse
FARM ANIMAL:  The agents - cow, sheep and chicken

Hypotheses
Different AGENTs will score significantly differently on the RATING (replicating the first study) 
These ratings are not fully described by either AGENT TYPE. Models that include AGENCY and EXPERIENCE ratings will be the best models. 

Note: Best models will be determined in two ways: by which model correctly predicts the largest number of significant effects as well as each model’s associated BIC score
Plots 
AGENCY by EXPERIENCE for each AGENT
AGENT TYPE on RATING
Plots of each model from Analysis 3 to gauge model adequacy
FOOD ORIENTATION by AGENT TYPE on RATING
Confirmatory Analyses
1. For each AGENT, RATING judgments will be judged to be significantly different from indifference (and differ between agents they lie) 

Two-tailed, one-sample T-Tests for each AGENT testing whether significantly above/below indifference on RATING


2. AGENCY and EXPERIENCE will significantly contribute to models predicting RATING 

Mixed Model Regression Predicting RATING
RATING ← AGENT TYPE * AGENCY * EXPERIENCE
Starting with a model of maximal random effects (removing each random effect until the model converges)

3. Is the model with AGENCY + EXPERIENCE the strongest model for predicting whether participants say Torture or Murder is Worse? Judged via BIC score and successful predictions of significant effects

Mixed Model Regression Predicting RATING
Model 1: AGENT TYPE 
Model 2: DIFFERENCE
Model 3: AGENT TYPE * DIFFERENCE
Starting with models of maximal random effects (removing each random effect until the model converges)

PLEASE SEE THE ATTACHED JAMOVI FILE UPLOADED TO THIS PRE-REGISTRATION FOR ALL CONFIRMATORY ANALYSES. 

PLEASE SEE THE ATTACHED PDF FILE TO SEE THE ANALYSIS PLAN IS NICER FORMATTING

q21.value: Holm corrected P-values (cut off > 0.5). Further details can be obtained through the uploaded Jamovi file.

q22.value: Participants will also be given a simple attention check and will be excluded if they fail this check.

q23.value: The experiment does not allow for participants to continue with the experiment without providing a response. Any participants who close their browser window without completing the experiment will be excluded.

q24.value:
We intend to look at FOOD ORIENTATION and FARM ANIMAL as predictors for exploratory purposes as well as see how they predict differences in AGENCY and EXPERIENCE Ratings.

We also intend to look at whether RESPONSE TIME is predicted by the interactions of AGENCY and EXPERIENCE and use RESPONSE TIME as a separate confidence measure

attributes.title: Varenicline Versus Cytisine for Smoking Cessation in the Primary Care Setting  - a Randomized Controlled Trial
attributes.description:
Brief Summary:
The overall goals of this study are to 1) assess awareness of an interest in the use of pharmacotherapy for smoking cessation in Croatia and Slovenia, countries in Central Europe with very high smoking prevalence, and 2) investigate whether cytisine is at least as feasible and effective as varenicline in helping smokers to quit in a real-life setting: family medicine practices in Croatia and Slovenia. The investigators propose to survey patients from 40 primary care practices (20 in Croatia and 20 in Slovenia) to assess the desire to quit smoking and awareness and interest in pharmacotherapy. Additionally, 380 patients with interest in quitting smoking will be randomly assigned to use varenicline or cytisine to help quit smoking.

The investigators hypothesize that cytisine is at least as feasible and effective as varenicline in helping smokers from primary care practices in Croatia and Slovenia to quit smoking
attributes.withdrawal_justification: The registration was withdrawn because it was not the final version but only a draft version - work in progress - and it got frozen and unavailable for the further changes

q1.value: The effectiveness of moral messaging on public health behaviors for COVID-19

q3.value:
We are in the face of a global pandemic threatening millions of lives around the globe. Public health experts believe that “individual behaviour will be crucial to control the spread of COVID-19” (Anderson et al. 2020, The Lancet). These behaviors include washing hands more frequently and for longer; avoiding public gatherings; cancelling travel plans; and keeping distance from others, because the virus is contagious even before people feel sick.
 
While some people agree that the moral thing to do is to take these actions in these circumstances, there are many different kinds of moral principles that people can draw on to justify their actions and attempt to persuade others. We might, for example, appeal to utilitarian moral theories focused on cost/benefit ratios and expected consequences (Everett et al. 2018, Psychological Review). We might appeal to deontological moral theories focused on notions of duties, rights, and responsibilities. Or we might appeal to more virtue based notions of moral exemplars and consider what an ideal person would do. As far as we are aware, there is almost no work directly exploring the persuasiveness of these different kinds of moral justifications on expected intentions to act, and certainly not in the context of this global pandemic. This is our first goal.
 
Just as it is critically important to understand the potential persuasiveness of these different moral framings, we also need to understand how people differentially trust and perceive those who give such messages. Our previous work has demonstrated that we differentially trust people based on whether they make more utilitarian or deontological decisions in a variety of different domains (Everett, Pizarro, & Crockett, 2016, JEPG; Everett et al. 2018, JESP), and we know that because trust is the cornerstone of society this can have incredibly important downstream consequences on our willingness to act. Importantly, our previous work suggests that different moral justifications can also be favoured depending on the kind of social role one has: whether the person is a leader in a position of authority (e.g. a public health commissioner) or a general citizen (e.g. a teacher). Even if, as we predict, deontological or virtue-based moral messaging will be more effective and lead to greater trust than utilitarian moral messaging, it might be that this effect is attenuated or even reversed when it comes from a person in authority, who is supposed to act more impartially and make cost/benefit decisions (Everett et al. 2018, JESP).
 
To study this, we will conduct an experiment on Prolific in which we present a purported Facebook appeal and vary the source of a message (leader vs citizen) and the content of that message (utilitarian vs deontological vs virtue ethics vs non-moral control). We then look at both first-order and second-order beliefs on likelihood of taking different protective actions to reduce spread, intent to share the post wider, and questions about perceptions of the person who posted it and trust in them and their message.

q4.value:
Behavioral intentions: We predict that moral justifications for public health behaviors will have a stronger effect on intentions to adopt public health behaviors (relative to no moral justification). We also predict that appealing to utilitarian justifications will be less effective than deontological or virtue-based justifications. However we are anticipating possible ceiling effects on these measures due to social desirability concerns.

Second order beliefs: We predict that moral justifications for public health behaviors will have a stronger effect on second order beliefs about others’ public health behaviors (relative to no moral justification). We also predict that appealing to utilitarian justifications will be less effective than deontological or virtue-based justifications. These measures may be more sensitive to our manipulations than behavioral intentions measures. 

Impressions of messenger: We predict that moral justifications for public health behaviors will make the speaker seem more moral and trustworthy (relative to no moral justification). We also predict that appealing to utilitarian justifications will make speakers seem less moral and trustworthy than deontological or virtue-based justifications (Everett et al, 2016, 2018).

Moderation of above effects by messenger identity: We predict that differences in effectiveness between moral message types will be less pronounced when the messenger is a leader compared to a citizen. Even if, as we predict, deontological or virtue-based moral messaging will be more effective and lead to greater trust than utilitarian moral messaging, it might be that this effect is attenuated or even reversed when it comes from a person in authority, who is supposed to act more impartially and make cost/benefit decisions (Everett et al. 2018, JESP).

Moderation of above effects by participants’ own utilitarian tendencies: We predict that the above effects will be more pronounced for participants who score lower on the Oxford Utilitarianism Scale (Kahane, Everett et al. 2018).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: We have a fully between-subjects design in which participants see a Facebook post from what is described as either a citizen (teacher) or leader (state director of education), where this person makes an argument/moral appeal for self-isolation/protective behaviour, and does this based on either deontological grounds (e.g. it is your duty as a citizen), utilitarian grounds (e.g. you must undergo self-sacrifice to advance the welfare of society at large), or virtue ethics (e.g. this is what a good person would do), or no moral appeal at all.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to a condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Using Prolific.ac, we will collect data from a representative samples for age, sex and ethnicity in the US.

q14.value: Power analyses show that to detect a small effect size (f = 0.10) with 90% power, we need a final sample of 1053 participants (and thus need to recruit at least 1100 to account for people who fail attention/manipulation checks and are excluded from analysis). We expect a small effect – at least on future intentions to act – but these small effects are incredibly important to know in this pandemic context, and this is why we need at least 90% power to detect these effects.

q15.value: We aim to collect N=1100 in a US representative sample on the factors of sex, age and ethnicity. However, given the time sensitive nature of the unfolding pandemic crisis, if it is not possible to collect the full nationally representative sample within 72 hours we will supplement the nationally representative sample with a convenience sample to reach the required N.

question.value:
1.     Source Condition
a.     Citizen
b.     Leader

2.     Message Condition
a.     Utilitarian (moral)
b.     Deontological (moral)
c.     Virtue Ethics (moral)
d.     Non-Moral

First-Order Behavioural Intentions
1.     After reading this message, how likely is it that you will always wash your hands whenever you enter work or come home, for at least 2 weeks, even if you feel sick? (1 = extremely unlikely, 7 = extremely likely)
2.     After reading this message, how likely is it that you will avoid public gatherings for at least 2 weeks, even if you don't feel sick?
3.     After reading this message, how likely is it that you will stay at home and avoid all social contact for at least 2 weeks, even if you don't feel sick?
4.     How likely is it that you would share this post to your own social media?

 Second-Order Beliefs 
1.     How likely is it that someone else who reads this would, for the next 2 weeks, always wash their hands whenever they enter work or come home, even if they don’t feel sick?
2.     How likely is it that someone else who reads this would avoid public gatherings for at least 2 weeks, even if they don't feel sick?
3.     How likely is it that someone else who reads this will stay at home and avoid all social contact for at least 2 weeks, even if they don't feel sick?
4.     How likely is it that someone else who reads this would cancel an upcoming foreign holiday they've already paid for, even if they feel sick?

Person Perception
1.     Think about the person who posted this message, Nicholas Newman. How trustworthy do you think they are? (1 = not trustworthy at all. 7 = extremely trustworthy)
2.     Think about the person who posted this message, Nicholas Newman. How moral, or a good a person do you think they are? (1 = very immoralbad, 7 = extremely moral/good)

COVID-19 Beliefs
1.     How much of a threat do you think COVID-19 (coronavirus) is? (1 = not a threat at all, 7 = extremely threatening)
2.     How likely do you think it is that you yourself will die as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic?
3.     How likely do you think it is that someone you know will die as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic?
4.     How responsible do you feel about your own role in mitigating further outbreak of COVID-19? (1 = not at all responsible, 7 = very responsible)
5.     How responsible do you think that people who do not stay at home self-isolating are for further outbreak of COVID-19? (1 = not at all responsible, 7 = very responsible)
6.     How much control do you think that people have over whether they stay at home and self-isolate? (1 = no control at all, 7 = complete control)
7. How unpleasant would it be for you personally to stay at home and avoid social contact for the next 2 weeks?
8. Over the past week, how often have you sought out information about the COVID-19 pandemic (e.g. news articles, video, social media posts, etc.)?
9. Are there currently any cases of COVID-19 in the city where you live?
10. Has anyone you know personally tested positive for coronavirus?


Forced-Choice Moral Messaging

registration_responses.q1: The effectiveness of moral messaging on public health behaviors for COVID-19
registration_responses.q3:
We are in the face of a global pandemic threatening millions of lives around the globe. Public health experts believe that “individual behaviour will be crucial to control the spread of COVID-19” (Anderson et al. 2020, The Lancet). These behaviors include washing hands more frequently and for longer; avoiding public gatherings; cancelling travel plans; and keeping distance from others, because the virus is contagious even before people feel sick.
 
While some people agree that the moral thing to do is to take these actions in these circumstances, there are many different kinds of moral principles that people can draw on to justify their actions and attempt to persuade others. We might, for example, appeal to utilitarian moral theories focused on cost/benefit ratios and expected consequences (Everett et al. 2018, Psychological Review). We might appeal to deontological moral theories focused on notions of duties, rights, and responsibilities. Or we might appeal to more virtue based notions of moral exemplars and consider what an ideal person would do. As far as we are aware, there is almost no work directly exploring the persuasiveness of these different kinds of moral justifications on expected intentions to act, and certainly not in the context of this global pandemic. This is our first goal.
 
Just as it is critically important to understand the potential persuasiveness of these different moral framings, we also need to understand how people differentially trust and perceive those who give such messages. Our previous work has demonstrated that we differentially trust people based on whether they make more utilitarian or deontological decisions in a variety of different domains (Everett, Pizarro, & Crockett, 2016, JEPG; Everett et al. 2018, JESP), and we know that because trust is the cornerstone of society this can have incredibly important downstream consequences on our willingness to act. Importantly, our previous work suggests that different moral justifications can also be favoured depending on the kind of social role one has: whether the person is a leader in a position of authority (e.g. a public health commissioner) or a general citizen (e.g. a teacher). Even if, as we predict, deontological or virtue-based moral messaging will be more effective and lead to greater trust than utilitarian moral messaging, it might be that this effect is attenuated or even reversed when it comes from a person in authority, who is supposed to act more impartially and make cost/benefit decisions (Everett et al. 2018, JESP).
 
To study this, we will conduct an experiment on Prolific in which we present a purported Facebook appeal and vary the source of a message (leader vs citizen) and the content of that message (utilitarian vs deontological vs virtue ethics vs non-moral control). We then look at both first-order and second-order beliefs on likelihood of taking different protective actions to reduce spread, intent to share the post wider, and questions about perceptions of the person who posted it and trust in them and their message.
registration_responses.q4:
Behavioral intentions: We predict that moral justifications for public health behaviors will have a stronger effect on intentions to adopt public health behaviors (relative to no moral justification). We also predict that appealing to utilitarian justifications will be less effective than deontological or virtue-based justifications. However we are anticipating possible ceiling effects on these measures due to social desirability concerns.

Second order beliefs: We predict that moral justifications for public health behaviors will have a stronger effect on second order beliefs about others’ public health behaviors (relative to no moral justification). We also predict that appealing to utilitarian justifications will be less effective than deontological or virtue-based justifications. These measures may be more sensitive to our manipulations than behavioral intentions measures. 

Impressions of messenger: We predict that moral justifications for public health behaviors will make the speaker seem more moral and trustworthy (relative to no moral justification). We also predict that appealing to utilitarian justifications will make speakers seem less moral and trustworthy than deontological or virtue-based justifications (Everett et al, 2016, 2018).

Moderation of above effects by messenger identity: We predict that differences in effectiveness between moral message types will be less pronounced when the messenger is a leader compared to a citizen. Even if, as we predict, deontological or virtue-based moral messaging will be more effective and lead to greater trust than utilitarian moral messaging, it might be that this effect is attenuated or even reversed when it comes from a person in authority, who is supposed to act more impartially and make cost/benefit decisions (Everett et al. 2018, JESP).

Moderation of above effects by participants’ own utilitarian tendencies: We predict that the above effects will be more pronounced for participants who score lower on the Oxford Utilitarianism Scale (Kahane, Everett et al. 2018).

attributes.title: Comparison of oral uracil-tegafur and intravenous fluorouracil as postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy among patients with locally advanced colon cancer:  A Nationwide Cohort Study and Meta-Analysis

q1.value: Comparison of oral uracil-tegafur and intravenous fluorouracil as postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy among patients with locally advanced colon cancer:  A Nationwide Cohort Study and Meta-Analysis

q3.value: Since the early 1990s, chemotherapy comprising fluorouracil (5-FU) has been a curative therapeutic choice for postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy. As an alternative, uracil-tegafur (UFT), oral drugs derived from 5-FU derivatives, has been commonly used. Despite some randomized control studies comparing the efficacy between UFT and 5-FU, it still lacks larger scale of population-based and long-term retrospective cohort study to clarify the effectiveness of UFT. Besides, we compare our results with available data from the literatures in a meta-analysis and provide the best evidence to this issue.

q4.value: UFT has similar effect to 5-FU in patients with locally advanced colon cancer receiving postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We conducted a population-based cohort study enrolling patients with locally advanced colon cancer receiving postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy with UFT or 5-FU from Taiwan National Health Insurance Research Database during 1996–2015 and further performed a meta-analysis incorporating four recent studies.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

question.value: We conducted a population-based cohort study enrolling patients with locally advanced colon cancer receiving postoperative adjuvant chemotherapy with UFT or 5-FU from Taiwan National Health Insurance Research Database during 1996–2015 and further performed a meta-analysis incorporating four recent studies.

q13.value: A PRISMA flow diagram of the inclusion of studies is shown in Supplement. Our database search identified 402 publications after removal of duplicates. After series of screening process, 27 articles were reviewed in full, from which 4 studies (2 randomized trials and 2 observational studies) were deemed eligible for inclusion. In total, 2,537 patients were included from the 4 studies.

question.value: The primary and secondary outcomes of interest were disease-free survival and overall survival, respectively. Data are presented as HR with 95% CIs.

To minimize the bias from the combining randomized and non-randomized evidence, we used the method of design-adjusted analysis, and reduced the weight carried by non-randomized studies. Given the expected between-study heterogeneity due to differences in patient populations, a random-effects DerSimonian-Laird model using the reverse invariance method was used to estimate the average measure of association. Heterogeneity was evaluated using the I square (I2) statistic and Cochran's Q test. Statistically significant heterogeneity was defined as I2 > 50% and Cochran's Q Test P < 0.1.

attributes.title: ALT's association with Emotions and Personality
attributes.description:
Study Design

A non-experimental design will be employed in two analyses,
1) with age and gender as control predictors, the ALT measures as the major predictors and facial emotion and personality identification as the major outcomes variables,
2) a comparison of the efficacy of the two face sets in terms of reliability and personality identification accuracy.

q1.value: ALT's association with Emotions and Personality

q2.value: Louise Reid, Dr Colin Joseph Hamilton

q3.value: Previous research suggests individuals with Autistic Spectrum Disorder (ASD) have impairments in social skills and may find it difficult to infer personality and emotions. Only one known study has been used to associate the relationship between Autistic Like Traits (ALT's) in the general population and the inference of emotions. and no known study for the inference of Big Five personality traits using a facial stimulus. This study will investigate the relationship between Autistic Like Traits and inference of personality and emotions, and if the relationship is dependent on the type of facial stimulus set used.

q4.value: The study has three hypotheses. The first hypothesis will be high scores of ALT’s will predict reduced accuracy to infer emotions. The second hypothesis will be high scores of ALT’s will predict reduced accuracy to infer each of the Big Five personality traits. The third hypothesis will be the facial stimuli sets used to infer personality traits will differ in the relationship with ALT’s.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A one factor repeated measures design. The independent variable is overall score for autistic like traits. The dependent variables are recognition accuracy and perceptual accuracy for the emotional recognition task, the overall trait accuracy for the Sacco and Brown (2018) facial stimulus set, and the overall trait accuracy for the Krammer and Ward (2010) facial stimulus .

q9.value: The study will randomize the items in the short form of Systemizing Quotient (SQ-Short) for the Autistic like Traits measure. The study will randomize the ERT task, and both the facial stimulus sets.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The sample will be recruited by advertising through an on-line poster and using the online research platform, SONA. The sample will be recruited via the social media platforms; Facebook, Reddit and Twitter using a link to the online platform Qualtrics.

q13.value: Our target sample is n = 89 opportunity volunteers. We will attempt to recruit up to 300, assuming that not all will complete the total task.

q14.value: A G Power analysis was used to calculate the sample size for this study.

q15.value: We will continue to recruit volunteers up till the 1st August 2020 to ensure we have a large sample size. We will post the link to Qualtrics on social media sights every other day.

question.value: The ALT’s will be measured using the short form of Systemizing Quotient (SQ-Short) overall scores. The recognition accuracy and the perceptual sensitivity on the Emotional Recognition Task (ERT) will be measured. The overall trait accuracy for the Krammer and Ward (2010) facial stimulus set and the overall trait accuracy for the Sacco and Brown (2018) facial stimulus set will be measured.
We will compute the mean scores on all the variables using SPSS.
A linear multiple regression will be used to analysis the data. The control variables will be age and gender.

q21.value: We will use a standard p<.05 criteria. Post-hoc analysis will be conducted if there is a significant effect in the data.

q22.value: A scatterplot will be created to check for any outliers. Any outliers which would drastically effect the data will be removed.

q23.value: Any incomplete and missing data will be removed prior to data analysis.

q24.value: We will look at the control variables age and gender.

attributes.title: Benevolent Sexism and the Traditional Sexual Script as Predictors of Sexual Dissatisfaction in Heterosexual Women
attributes.description: This study aims to investigate how women's benevolently sexist attitudes are associated with their adoption of the traditional sex script and their sexual satisfaction

q1.value: Benevolent Sexism and the Traditional Sexual Script as Predictors of Sexual Dissatisfaction in Heterosexual Women

q2.value: Harrison Lee, Sarah Bonell, Sam Pearson, Fiona Barlow

q3.value:
Sexual satisfaction plays an integral role in the health and wellbeing of women (Mulhall et al., 2008; Stephenson & Meston, 2015). As such, it is important that we understand factors that might hinder women’s capacity to achieve this satisfaction (Glick & Fiske, 1997). Benevolent sexism encompasses subjectively positive but patronizing attitudes toward women; for instance, that female passivity ought to be romanticized and that women ought to be dependent on men (Glick et al., 2015; Harris et al., 2016). In women, benevolent sexism typically manifests as the belief that oneself and other women should adhere to traditional gender roles (i.e. caregiver; Gaunt, 2013). Harris and colleagues (2016) found that women’s benevolently sexist attitudes were indirectly associated with how frequently they reached orgasm; that is, women higher in benevolent sexism orgasmed less often. Given that orgasm frequency is predictive of sexual satisfaction, we have reason to believe that benevolent sexism might predict decreased sexual satisfaction in women (Haning et al., 2007). The purpose of the present study will therefore be to explore the mechanism through which women’s benevolently sexist attitudes reduce their sexual satisfaction. Namely, we implicate the Traditional Sexual Script (TSS) – a schema that dictates how men and women stereotypically ought to behave during intercourse – as a means through which benevolently sexist women come to be sexually unsatisfied (O’Sullivan & Byers, 1992). 

In the TSS, women are considered the ‘gatekeepers’ of sex; their worth and desirability is dictated by their initial reluctance, and subsequent submission, toward engaging in sexual activity. They are expected to remain passive throughout being sexually pursued, as well as during intercourse itself (Byers, 1996; Wiederman, 2005). Previous literature has demonstrated that women who adopt a submissive role during sex report experiencing less sexual arousal and greater difficulty becoming aroused (Sanchez et al., 2006). Given that arousal is associated with sexual satisfaction, these results suggest that submissiveness during sex is associated with decreased satisfaction (Sánchez-Fuentes et al., 2014). We therefore propose that TSS adoption might also be associated with decreased sexual satisfaction in women, given that female sexual submissiveness is an integral component of the TSS (Masters et al., 2013). In that being said, Sanchez and colleagues (2012) found that sexually submissive behaviour only predicted sexual dissatisfaction in women when the adoption of this behaviour was inconsistent with women’s sexual preferences; that is, only women who reported having a preference for being dominant during sexual encounters were dissatisfied when they partook in submissive sexual behaviour. We therefore conclude that TSS adoption might only reduce sexual satisfaction in women for whom this adoption is not in keeping with their sexual preferences.

q4.value: The present study aims to investigate the nature of the relationship between benevolent sexism, the TSS, and sexual satisfaction in heterosexual women. We hypothesise that an indirect relationship will exist between benevolently sexist attitudes and sexual satisfaction, such that benevolent sexism will lead to increased adoption of the TSS, which in turn will lead to a decrease in sexual satisfaction. In line with Sanchez et al. (2012), we also hypothesise that the relationship between TSS adoption and sexual satisfaction will be moderated by sexual preferences, such that adopting the TSS will only negatively affect sexual satisfaction among women who do not enjoy being submissive (please see “Figure x” which summarises our hypotheses).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Correlational design with four factors: benevolent sexism, adoption of the TSS, sexual satisfaction, and enjoying submissiveness.

q9.value: The order in which participants complete the four measured variables will be randomised. This randomisation process will be implemented using Qualtrics survey software.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited from the Mturk online platform. Inclusion criteria are being a woman, being heterosexual, being 18 years or older, and having had sex with a man. Potential participants will be asked to complete a pre-screening survey to ensure that they meet these inclusion criteria. Participants who are eligible for the study will be paid $1.33 (US Dollars) for the time it takes them to complete the 10 minute study.

q13.value: Two hundred and eighty participants will be recruited to participate in this study.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis using Schoemann et. al’s (2017) schoam4 package for the R statistical computing language (R Core Team, 2019). Using the bivariate effect sizes from Harris and colleagues (2016) we found that 250 participants would be required to reach our target power of 0.95. Therefore, to allow for attrition, 280 participants will be recruited for this study.

question.value:
Benevolent sexism will be assessed using the benevolent sexism subscale from “The Ambivalent Sexism Inventory” (Glick & Fiske, 1997). Participants will be asked to complete the 11-items from this subscale which involves indicating the extent to which they agree or disagree with statements pertaining benevolently sexist attitudes (e.g., “in a disaster, women ought not necessarily to be rescued before men). Participants will respond to these items on 6-point Likert scales (where 0 = disagree strongly, 5 = agree strongly), with three items being negatively worded and reverse scored. Higher scores will indicate more benevolently sexist attitudes.

Adoption of the TSS will be assessed by asking participants questions about how often they engage in submissive behaviour during sexual activity. Participants will be asked to complete 4-items (as used in Sanchez et al., 2012) which involves indicating the extent to which they agree or disagree with the following statements: “I tend to take on the more passive role during sexual activity,” “I tend to take on the submissive role during sexual activity,” “I am the passive one in my sexual relationships,” and “I tend to take on the more dominant role during sexual activity”. Participants will respond to these items on 7-point Likert scales (where 1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree), with the last item being reverse scored. Higher scores will indicate partaking in more sexually submissive behaviour.  

Sexual satisfaction will be assessed using the Global Measure of Sexual Satisfaction – revised (GMSEX: Lawrence & Byers, 1998). Participants will be asked to please rate the sexual relationships they experience with men on the following five 7-point bipolar scales: (i) bad – good, (ii) unpleasant – pleasant, (iii) negative – positive, (iv) unsatisfying – satisfying, and (v) worthless – valuable. Higher scores will indicate more sexual satisfaction. 

Enjoyment of sexual submission will be assessed by asking participants the following three items (as used in Sanchez et al., 2012): “I find it arousing when my partner is the aggressive one in bed,” “I think it is sexy when my partner takes control in bed,” and “I think it is very exciting when my partner leads our sexual experiences”. Participants will respond to these items on 7-point Likert scales (where 1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree). Higher scores will indicate more enjoyment from partaking in sexually submissive behaviour.

For the measures assessing benevolent sexism, adoption of the TSS, and enjoyment of sexual submission – total scores will be calculated by averaging all items for each scale. For the measure assessing sexual satisfaction – total scores will be calculated by summing all scores, such that they fall between 5 and 35.

Bivariate correlations (Pearson’s r) will be calculated between benevolent sexism, adoption of the TSS, enjoyment of sexual submission and sexual satisfaction. These will serve as a preliminary test of our predictions

Moderated Mediation

We will use moderated mediation as used in Hayes and Scharkow (2013) to explore the effect of benevolent sexism on sexual satisfaction through the adoption of the TSS.

Confirmatory hypothesis 1: We hypothesise a negative indirect relationship between benevolently sexist attitudes and sexual satisfaction, such that benevolent sexism will lead to increased adoption of the TSS, which in turn will lead to a decrease in sexual satisfaction. This relationship will be conditional on female enjoyment of sexual submission and will be attenuated for women who enjoy sexual submissiveness (see figure x). 

Confirmatory hypothesis 1: we will consider this hypothesis fully supported if the following conditions are met: (1) the index of moderated mediation is significant, (2) the indirect negative effect of benevolent sexism on sexual satisfaction through adoption of the TSS of is significant and negative for females that are -1SD below the mean for enjoyment of sexual submissiveness, and (3) the direct effect of benevolent sexism on the adoption of the TSS is significant.

q22.value: During the study, participants will be asked to answer two attention check questions. After participants read the participant information sheet, they will be asked “what is this study about?” Participants can answer this attention check question by selecting either a) sexual habits and satisfaction, b) workplace habits and satisfaction, c) friendship habits and satisfaction, or d) none of the above. Participants who do not select a) will be excluded from participating in the study. While participants are answering the measured variables, they will be asked to complete the item, “if you are paying attention, please click 1”. Participants who do not select 1 will be excluded from the analyses.

q23.value: Any missing data will be treated under the guidelines of Pigott (2001), where participants will be excluded from the final sample if they are missing at least 50% of their data.

registration_responses.q1: Benevolent Sexism and the Traditional Sexual Script as Predictors of Sexual Dissatisfaction in Heterosexual Women
registration_responses.q2: Harrison Lee, Sarah Bonell, Sam Pearson, Fiona Barlow
registration_responses.q3:
Sexual satisfaction plays an integral role in the health and wellbeing of women (Mulhall et al., 2008; Stephenson & Meston, 2015). As such, it is important that we understand factors that might hinder women’s capacity to achieve this satisfaction (Glick & Fiske, 1997). Benevolent sexism encompasses subjectively positive but patronizing attitudes toward women; for instance, that female passivity ought to be romanticized and that women ought to be dependent on men (Glick et al., 2015; Harris et al., 2016). In women, benevolent sexism typically manifests as the belief that oneself and other women should adhere to traditional gender roles (i.e. caregiver; Gaunt, 2013). Harris and colleagues (2016) found that women’s benevolently sexist attitudes were indirectly associated with how frequently they reached orgasm; that is, women higher in benevolent sexism orgasmed less often. Given that orgasm frequency is predictive of sexual satisfaction, we have reason to believe that benevolent sexism might predict decreased sexual satisfaction in women (Haning et al., 2007). The purpose of the present study will therefore be to explore the mechanism through which women’s benevolently sexist attitudes reduce their sexual satisfaction. Namely, we implicate the Traditional Sexual Script (TSS) – a schema that dictates how men and women stereotypically ought to behave during intercourse – as a means through which benevolently sexist women come to be sexually unsatisfied (O’Sullivan & Byers, 1992). 

In the TSS, women are considered the ‘gatekeepers’ of sex; their worth and desirability is dictated by their initial reluctance, and subsequent submission, toward engaging in sexual activity. They are expected to remain passive throughout being sexually pursued, as well as during intercourse itself (Byers, 1996; Wiederman, 2005). Previous literature has demonstrated that women who adopt a submissive role during sex report experiencing less sexual arousal and greater difficulty becoming aroused (Sanchez et al., 2006). Given that arousal is associated with sexual satisfaction, these results suggest that submissiveness during sex is associated with decreased satisfaction (Sánchez-Fuentes et al., 2014). We therefore propose that TSS adoption might also be associated with decreased sexual satisfaction in women, given that female sexual submissiveness is an integral component of the TSS (Masters et al., 2013). In that being said, Sanchez and colleagues (2012) found that sexually submissive behaviour only predicted sexual dissatisfaction in women when the adoption of this behaviour was inconsistent with women’s sexual preferences; that is, only women who reported having a preference for being dominant during sexual encounters were dissatisfied when they partook in submissive sexual behaviour. We therefore conclude that TSS adoption might only reduce sexual satisfaction in women for whom this adoption is not in keeping with their sexual preferences.
registration_responses.q4: The present study aims to investigate the nature of the relationship between benevolent sexism, the TSS, and sexual satisfaction in heterosexual women. We hypothesise that an indirect relationship will exist between benevolently sexist attitudes and sexual satisfaction, such that benevolent sexism will lead to increased adoption of the TSS, which in turn will lead to a decrease in sexual satisfaction. In line with Sanchez et al. (2012), we also hypothesise that the relationship between TSS adoption and sexual satisfaction will be moderated by sexual preferences, such that adopting the TSS will only negatively affect sexual satisfaction among women who do not enjoy being submissive (please see “Figure x” which summarises our hypotheses).

Therefore, to allow for attrition, 280 participants will be recruited for this study.

attributes.title: Affective incongruence in PTSD and resilience

q1.value: The role of emotions in resilience

q2.value: Anna Semenchenko, McKenzie Lockett, Sander Koole

q3.value:
Adverse life events can cause psychopathology. But, remarkably, many individuals experience only mild disruptions and quickly return to healthy functioning (Bonanno, 2005). Understanding the mechanisms of creating resilience, defined as the ability to bounce back from stress (Smith, Dalen, Wiggins, Tooley, Christopher, & Bernard, 2008), is essential. It can inform future preventative interventions by using a transdiagnostic approach, which can be beneficial given high overlap among psychological disorders (Koole, Schwager, & Rothermund, 2015).
In daily life individuals high in resilience experience negative affect as often  as individuals low in resilience (Montpetit, Bergeman, Deboeck, Tiberio, & Boker, 2010). In the study by Waugh, Thompson and Gotlib (2011) resilience didn’t predict negative affect while viewing negative images. What differentiates the participants high in resilience is their greater recovery from stress (Montpetit, Bergeman, Deboeck, Tiberio, & Boker, 2010), which results in overall lower negative affect. Markovitz, Schrooten, Arntz, & Peters (2015) showed that resilience predicts lower self-reported negative affect and that this difference increases in high stress conditions (it is higher for cancer patients). 
There is growing consensus that positive affect is not just an opposite of negative affect. Positive emotions might play their own special role in resilience. Kalisch, Müller, & Tüscher (2015) propose that a positive appraisal style is a primary mechanism that protects individuals from the negative psychological effects of adversity. They argue that a quick recovery of mental health is an active process that relies on mechanisms that allow an individual to adjust stress responses to an optimal level. The authors suggest that aversive motivation causes stress, and the most effective way to prevent stress-related dysfunction is to limit aversion. According to the positive appraisal style theory of resilience (PASTOR) (Kalish et al., 2015), positive appraisal is the mechanism that lowers the frequency of strong aversive states. Thus, a general tendency for positive appraisal increases resilience. 
Broaden-and-build theory (Fredrickson, 2004) supports the idea of the importance of positive emotions for resilience. The theory states that positive emotions broaden an individual's thought-action repertoire. At times of adversity, positive emotions may help to recognize more possible coping strategies and solutions to the problem (Gloria, & Steinhardt, 2016). Additionally, the broaden-and-build theory proposes that by promoting the discovery of novel actions, ideas, and social bonds, positive emotions build resources. Thus, an individual can accumulate resources during low-stress times to increase the chances of successful coping later in life. 
A particular type of positive emotion, extended trust, a tendency towards positive feelings over one’s existence (Kuhl, Quirin, & Koole, 2015), is of particular importance. Having inner security and trust in the world can help to cope with painful experiences (Kuhl, Quirin, & Koole, 2015).  Lack of extended trust predicts psychological symptoms (Kuhl, Mitina, & Koole, 2017). 
Moderate levels of positive emotions may buffer stress by decreasing the negative arousal in stressful situations (Pressman & Cohen, 2005). A high level of positive emotion, on the opposite, can be harmful. It might pose a physiological burden and might result in underestimating potential threats and adoption of inappropriate coping strategies (Pressman & Cohen, 2005). Higher volatility of positive emotion is associated with lower well-being and greater depression and anxiety (Gruber, Kogan, Quoidbach, & Mauss, 2013). Koole, Schwager, and Rothermund (2015) argue that resilience is based on a steady emotional balance rather than on general positivity bias. According to the authors, stable emotional balance is achieved through counter-regulation, a dynamic processing bias towards positive stimuli in negative contexts, and negative stimuli in positive contexts (Koole et al., 2015). 
Empirical evidence shows that resilience is associated with higher positive emotions (Gloria & Steinhardt, 2016). The study by Markovitz, Schrooten, Arntz, & Peters (2015) supports the idea that resilient individuals maintain positive appraisal style in better times. In the study resilience predicted higher positive emotions and this relationship was not moderated by group type (cancer patients, i.e. high stress situation, vs. control group). The results of the study by Waugh, Thompson, and Gotlib (2011) are harder to interpret. In the study the participants higher in trait resilience reported higher positive affect while viewing positive images. One may interpret the results as showing that the participants high in resilience experience more positive emotions even in better times. Alternatively, one can argue that the participants high in resilience are balancing their emotions as they are being presented with a mix of negative and positive emotions. They are using positive emotions to recover from negative emotions elicited by previous negative images. 
The theories discussed above concur that positive emotions contribute to resilience in stressful situations. However, they disagree on whether resilient individuals have stronger or weaker responses to positive stimuli in low-stress conditions than individuals low in resilience. In the present study, we will test whether resilience is associated with higher positive affect during less stressful times. Based on the PASTOR and the broaden-and-build theories, we predict that higher resilience will be associated with higher positive affect not only in stressful but also during less stressful times. 

Role of emotional congruence in resilience
Emotional self-awareness has been identified as a factor contributing to resilience. Empirical evidence shows that emotional self-awareness was associated with higher resilience (Armstrong, Galligan, & Critchley, 2011). A longitudinal study has identified a lack of emotional awareness as a risk factor for the development and maintenance of depression and anxiety in children and adolescents (Kranzler, Young, Hankin, Abela, Elias, & Selby, 2016). In extreme case of alexithymia, the patients are unaware of their emotions and struggle to deploy coping mechanisms in time, which might result in longer periods of recovery from stressful events (Naatanen, Ryynanen, & Keltikangas-Jarvinen, 1999). In a study by Naatanen et al. (1999), the participants high in alexithymia underestimated their physiological response during a stressful stimulus but overestimated their physiological response during the recovery. 
Emotional self-awareness is a trait measure, based on self-report. A parallel state measure, affective congruence (i.e., congruence between implicit and explicit affect) have not been widely studied. A correlational study by McKenzie Lockett and Sander Koole (2019) showed that affective incongruence is associated with higher PTSD symptoms. In the study, only the participants with high PTSD symptoms reported incongruent negative affect (i.e., implicit and explicit measures were not correlated). 
The present study is the first to test the relationship between resilience and affective congruence. Kalisch, Müller, & Tüscher (2015) state that mechanisms that help to fine-tune stress response to an optimal level, to switch to a more efficient coping strategy, and to terminate the stress response when it is no longer necessary are likely to prevent psychological dysfunctions. We suggest that affective congruence facilitates all of the three processes, contributing to the individual's resilience. In the present correlational study, we hypothesize that individuals higher in affective congruence will report higher resilience. In line with previous findings (Ssenyonga, Owens, & Olema, 2013) we expect resilience to be associated with lower PTSD symptoms. In addition, we hypothesize that this relationship will be mediated by affective congruence.

3.	Resilience is associated with higher negative and positive affective congruence.

question.value: Three hundred workers will be hired through Mturk. The participants have to satisfy the following criteria: US location, 99% approval rating, at least 100 HITs completed. The participants will be paid 3.75 USD for the study.

Brief Resilience Scale (BRS) (Smith, Dalen, Wiggins, Tooley, Christopher, & Bernard, 2008) will measure resilience. The participants will indicate on a 5-point scale (1 = strongly disagree, 5 = strongly agree) their agreement to six items (e.g., “I tend to bounce back quickly after hard times”). After items two, four and six are reverse-coded, the final score is calculated as a mean of six items.
Life stress questionnaire is a translation of a measure by Fröhlich, & Kuhl (2003). The participants will indicate on a 5-point scale (1 = not at all, 5 = extremely) their agreement to eight statements (e.g., “I have to overcome a lot of difficulties”) in relation to their current life situation. The final score is calculated as a mean of eight items.
IPANAT (Quirin, Kazén, & Kuhl, 2009) will measure implicit affect. IPANAT includes 36 items, which ask participants to rate the degree to which six artificial words (SAFME, VIKES, TUNBA, TALEP, BELNI, and SUKOV) sound like six mood adjectives (happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited) on a four-point scale ( 1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well). The score of the positive implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The score of the negative implicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods. 
The questionnaire for explicit affect will mimic IPANAT by asking the participants to rate how happy, cheerful, energetic, helpless, tense, and inhibited they feel right now on a four-point scale (1 = doesn’t fit at all, 4 = fits very well). The score of the positive explicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of happy, cheerful and energetic moods.  The score of the negative explicit affect scale will be calculated as a mean of helpless, tense and inhibited moods. 
Trauma symptoms will be measured by the PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 (Weathers, , Litz, Keane, Palmieri, Marx, & Schnurr, 2013). The participants will indicate on a 5-point Likert scale (0 = not at all, 4 = extremely) to which extent they experience each of the twenty symptoms associated with PTSD. The total symptom severity score is calculated by adding the scores for all 20 items.

To test the hypotheses one and two, we will use four general linear models for four dependent variables (explicit negative affect, implicit negative affect, explicit positive affect and implicit positive affect).  Life stress, resilience, and interaction between life-stress and resilience will be independent variables. We will conduct a simple slope analysis for the resilience level of 1SD above the mean and 1SD below the mean.
We will use a general linear model to test the hypothesis three (explicit negative affect as a dependent variable; implicit negative affect, resilience, and interaction between implicit negative affect and resilience as independent variables). We will conduct a simple slope analysis for the resilience level of 1SD above the mean and 1SD below the mean. We will repeat the procedure for implicit and explicit positive affect.

registration_responses.q2: Anna Semenchenko, McKenzie Lockett, Sander Koole
registration_responses.q3:
Adverse life events can cause psychopathology. But, remarkably, many individuals experience only mild disruptions and quickly return to healthy functioning (Bonanno, 2005). Understanding the mechanisms of creating resilience, defined as the ability to bounce back from stress (Smith, Dalen, Wiggins, Tooley, Christopher, & Bernard, 2008), is essential. It can inform future preventative interventions by using a transdiagnostic approach, which can be beneficial given high overlap among psychological disorders (Koole, Schwager, & Rothermund, 2015).
In daily life individuals high in resilience experience negative affect as often  as individuals low in resilience (Montpetit, Bergeman, Deboeck, Tiberio, & Boker, 2010). In the study by Waugh, Thompson and Gotlib (2011) resilience didn’t predict negative affect while viewing negative images. What differentiates the participants high in resilience is their greater recovery from stress (Montpetit, Bergeman, Deboeck, Tiberio, & Boker, 2010), which results in overall lower negative affect. Markovitz, Schrooten, Arntz, & Peters (2015) showed that resilience predicts lower self-reported negative affect and that this difference increases in high stress conditions (it is higher for cancer patients). 
There is growing consensus that positive affect is not just an opposite of negative affect. Positive emotions might play their own special role in resilience. Kalisch, Müller, & Tüscher (2015) propose that a positive appraisal style is a primary mechanism that protects individuals from the negative psychological effects of adversity. They argue that a quick recovery of mental health is an active process that relies on mechanisms that allow an individual to adjust stress responses to an optimal level. The authors suggest that aversive motivation causes stress, and the most effective way to prevent stress-related dysfunction is to limit aversion. According to the positive appraisal style theory of resilience (PASTOR) (Kalish et al., 2015), positive appraisal is the mechanism that lowers the frequency of strong aversive states. Thus, a general tendency for positive appraisal increases resilience. 
Broaden-and-build theory (Fredrickson, 2004) supports the idea of the importance of positive emotions for resilience. The theory states that positive emotions broaden an individual's thought-action repertoire. At times of adversity, positive emotions may help to recognize more possible coping strategies and solutions to the problem (Gloria, & Steinhardt, 2016). Additionally, the broaden-and-build theory proposes that by promoting the discovery of novel actions, ideas, and social bonds, positive emotions build resources. Thus, an individual can accumulate resources during low-stress times to increase the chances of successful coping later in life. 
A particular type of positive emotion, extended trust, a tendency towards positive feelings over one’s existence (Kuhl, Quirin, & Koole, 2015), is of particular importance. Having inner security and trust in the world can help to cope with painful experiences (Kuhl, Quirin, & Koole, 2015).  Lack of extended trust predicts psychological symptoms (Kuhl, Mitina, & Koole, 2017). 
Moderate levels of positive emotions may buffer stress by decreasing the negative arousal in stressful situations (Pressman & Cohen, 2005). A high level of positive emotion, on the opposite, can be harmful. It might pose a physiological burden and might result in underestimating potential threats and adoption of inappropriate coping strategies (Pressman & Cohen, 2005). Higher volatility of positive emotion is associated with lower well-being and greater depression and anxiety (Gruber, Kogan, Quoidbach, & Mauss, 2013). Koole, Schwager, and Rothermund (2015) argue that resilience is based on a steady emotional balance rather than on general positivity bias. According to the authors, stable emotional balance is achieved through counter-regulation, a dynamic processing bias towards positive stimuli in negative contexts, and negative stimuli in positive contexts (Koole et al., 2015). 
Empirical evidence shows that resilience is associated with higher positive emotions (Gloria & Steinhardt, 2016). The study by Markovitz, Schrooten, Arntz, & Peters (2015) supports the idea that resilient individuals maintain positive appraisal style in better times. In the study resilience predicted higher positive emotions and this relationship was not moderated by group type (cancer patients, i.e. high stress situation, vs. control group). The results of the study by Waugh, Thompson, and Gotlib (2011) are harder to interpret. In the study the participants higher in trait resilience reported higher positive affect while viewing positive images. One may interpret the results as showing that the participants high in resilience experience more positive emotions even in better times. Alternatively, one can argue that the participants high in resilience are balancing their emotions as they are being presented with a mix of negative and positive emotions. They are using positive emotions to recover from negative emotions elicited by previous negative images. 
The theories discussed above concur that positive emotions contribute to resilience in stressful situations. However, they disagree on whether resilient individuals have stronger or weaker responses to positive stimuli in low-stress conditions than individuals low in resilience. In the present study, we will test whether resilience is associated with higher positive affect during less stressful times. Based on the PASTOR and the broaden-and-build theories, we predict that higher resilience will be associated with higher positive affect not only in stressful but also during less stressful times.
